intro: Rubus hirtus var. bellardii, commonly known as the Bellard’s bramble, is a deciduous shrub native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits known as drupes, which are typically red or black when mature. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and local biodiversity.
